Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Regional Atmospheric Chemistry: State-of-the-art Measurement and Modeling in the Pacific Northwest
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a renewal of the REU site at the Laboratory for Atmospheric Research (LAR) at Washington State University (WSU), which for many years has successfully engaged undergraduate students in research activities involving atmospheric chemistry, air quality, and climate change. Ten students will be recruited each summer, targeting underrepresented communities in the Pacific Northwest (including Northwest Indian College and Columbia Basin College) and students funded through WSU's Undergraduate Research Opportunity (URO) program. During the 9.5-week program, students will participate in several half-day workshops focusing on atmospheric chemistry, measurement and modeling techniques, data interpretation, and scientific communication. In parallel with the workshops, students will be trained on the specific research tools required for their individual projects and will conduct these projects under the mentorship of faculty and graduate students. The individual projects will be part of LAR externally-funded research programs that focus on current problems in atmospheric chemistry. The summer will culminate with poster presentations at the WSU Undergraduate Research Symposium.

The focus on atmospheric chemistry, air quality, and climate change will foster the participants' appreciation for the importance of interdisciplinary and collaborative research. It will also encourage some students to pursue graduate school opportunities and careers in an environmental field. By targeting underrepresented groups outside WSU, the REU renewal will help increase diversity both within the program and across broader engineering and scientific disciplines. Before, during, and after their summer at WSU, REU participants will be interviewed to determine how their views of research were affected by the program. This assessment of the program's impact on participants' beliefs and perspectives regarding scientific research will contribute to the broader education community and also help guide future REU programs nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Program trained 30 undergraduate students over three years at Washington State University (WSU). The Site, entitled: Regional Atmospheric Chemistry: State-of-the-art Measurement and Modeling in the Pacific Northwest, gave students hands-on experience conducting authentic research with a faculty mentor. Faculty and students were part of the Laboratory for Atmospheric Research (LAR), within the Civil and Environmental Engineering Dept. at WSU. During the 9 week summer experience, students participated in skill development workshops, professional development workshops, training in a specific research area, and presenting their research in the form of a poster symposium. Students were engaged in activities to help them understand the broad scope of atmospheric chemistry, air quality and climate change research. Students worked side by side with faculty, graduate students and other REU students within a community of scholars. The 30 REU participants were from various institutions, and were collectively 53% female, 47% male,  30% underrepresented, and 27% from small universities or community colleges that do not have research opportunities. Students were encouraged to present their research at a National conference such as the American Meteorological Society Annual Meeting, and 7 (23%) of the students did this through funding from this grant. Students were also provided opportunities to learn about career and graduate school options, and in general exposed to positive and productive beliefs about Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields in hopes of developing our future STEM workforce.

Since we are now in our 6th year of NSF funding, many of the students that have participated have graduated and moved on in their careers. The following information has been collected from the longitudinal survey, to try and understand how this REU program impacts retention in the STEM discipline. Thus information presented below includes students funded through this program beyond the past three years.

The survey was administered via SurveyMonkey to all previous participants from 2009 – 2013 (5 years). A total of 61 students were included in this survey (including 18 funded through department funds or grants and 43 NSF funded students). The following lists provides highlights from the survey indicating the highly effective nature of our program:

  • The response on the survey was 38 or 62%.
  • 47% (18) of the students are currently enrolled (undergraduate or graduate school) and 53% (20) are no longer enrolled. 89% (33) have graduated with an undergraduate degree. All but one graduated in a STEM discipline, with environmental science and environmental engineering being the most common majors.
  • The next set of questions were along the lines of “The LAR REU program…encouraged me to pursue a career in science or engineering, or it provided me with skills necessary to prepare for graduate school, or it gave me confidence to know that I could succeed in graduate school if I chose to attend”. Students responded to each question using a 5 point Likert scale of “strongly disagree = 1; neutral = 3; strongly agree = 5”. For each of the 12 questions, the average score was greater than 4, with many of them close to 4.5, indicating that all participants answered each question with “agree” or “strongly agree”.
  • Overall, when asked to rate their satisfaction with the LAR REU program, the average response was 4.78, with 81% indicating “very satisfied”, 16% “somewhat satisfied”, and 3% “neutral”.
  • 100% of the students answered yes, that the REU program impacted their level of preparation and/or success in reaching their education goals.
